thread.title: From festivals to celebration of television and charity treks: Best things to do this week
thread.title_full: From festivals to celebration of television and charity treks: Best things to do this week

title: From festivals to celebration of television and charity treks: Best things to do this week
text:
From festivals to celebration of television and charity treks: Best things to do this week From festivals to celebration of television and charity treks: Best things to do this week A TREK for charity, a freedom festival and a celebration of television and radio come under the spotlight this week. PUBLISHED: PUBLISHED: 00:01, Sun, Aug 30, 2015 PH 
Do 
Get into your stride and challenge your fitness for charity at the Peak District National Park on September 5 and 6. 
Organised by Global Adventure Challenges, Trekfest Peak District offers 13, 27 and 54-mile treks for all abilities, taking walkers through a network of beautiful footpaths, bridleways and rural scenery. It begins and ends in the picturesque Hope Valley. Tickets cost from £60. Register now at trekfest.org.uk . 
Go to 
Hull’s Freedom Festival gets underway next week, marking the anniversary of the abolition of slavery in the UK. From Friday to Sunday, the next UK City of Culture (in 2017) will transform its city streets and quiet marina into a hub of art, dance, music, workshops and entertainment for all ages. 
This year’s line-up includes a talk with famous novelist Bonnie Greer, music from BBC A-listed band Spring King and a contemporary theatre performance of the silent film Phantom Of The Opera. For details, visit freedomfestival.co.uk . 
Book 
Celebrate the best of television, radio and literature at Hampton Court Palace from September 24 to 27, where 70 live events including talks, workshops, exhibits and screenings reveal the inside story on how great TV and radio is achieved. 
This year’s famous faces will include Sir David Attenborough, Sir Bruce Forsyth and Paul Hollywood, alongside top programmes The Archers, Doctor Who and Gogglebox. Be inspired by authors and illustrators, learn about the BAFTAs and explore the ins and outs of entertainment production. Visit radiotimesfestival.com . 
Shop 
Let your fingers do the shopping with Next’s new next-day delivery service. The high-street store is offering an order-by-midnight service from next month, operating from Sundays to Fridays inclusive. 
Customers shopping at home from next.co.uk or Next Directory will enjoy next-day delivery on clothes, gifts and brands including Jigsaw and Mint Velvet. Delivery costs £3.99 or orders can be collected from your nearest Next store free of charge. It’s only available to mainland UK delivery addresses. Related articles
